questions.answer_description: Bluejacking is the sending of unsolicited messages over Bluetooth to Bluetooth-enabled devices such as mobile phones, PDAs or laptop computers, sending a vCard which typically contains a message in the name field (i.e., for bluedating or bluechat) to another Bluetooth-enabled device via the OBEX protocol.
questions.question_text: Which of the following attack types is being carried out where a target is being sent unsolicited messages via Bluetooth?

discussion.content: Bluejacking is the sending of unsolicited messages over Bluetooth to Bluetooth-enabled devices such as mobile phones, PDAs or laptop computers, sending a vCard which typically contains a message in the name field (i.e., for bluedating or bluechat) to another Bluetooth-enabled device via the OBEX protocol.

questions.answer_description: Asymmetric algorithms use two keys to encrypt and decrypt data. These asymmetric keys are referred to as the public key and the private key. The sender uses the public key to encrypt a message, and the receiver uses the private key to decrypt the message; what one key does, the other one undoes.
questions.question_text:
Joe is exchanging encrypted email with another party. Joe encrypts the initial email with a key. When Joe receives a response, he is unable to decrypt the response with the same key he used initially.
Which of the following would explain the situation?

choices.A: An ephemeral key was used for one of the messages
choices.B: A stream cipher was used for the initial email; a block cipher was used for the reply
choices.C: Out-of-band key exchange has taken place

discussion.content: Joe would need to use his Private key to decrypt the response. When he sent the email he used other party’s public key to encrypt

comments.content: Asymmetric algorithms use two keys to encrypt and decrypt data. These asymmetric keys are referred to as the public key and the private key. The sender uses the public key to encrypt a message, and the receiver uses the private key to decrypt the message; what one key does, the other one undoes.

discussion.content: I too initially missed read the statement he is “unable to decrypt” the message.
The key is “when he receives a response” this is a common example of Bob & Sally using asymmetric keys. Public and private keys.

Why it is D???
decryption and encryption with the same key means symmetric .....

comments.content: Joe can't use the same key he used to encrypt the initial message. he will have to use a private key on the received message to be able to decrypt the message. answer is D.

discussion.content:
Authority - If it is possible to convince the person you are attempting to trick that
you are in a position of authority, they may be less likely to question your
request. That position of authority could be upper management, tech support,
HR, or law enforcement.

There is also scarcity emphasized. It's like asking " Is Orange a color or a fruit "
School is not a trick. smh

comments.content: This is not scarcity. It doesn't mention anything is limited or a time frame. It is only authority.
But it scares people that they will be disciplined...

This is a language carrier.
Scarcity does not mean scary.

Scarcity definition: insufficiency or shortness of supply;
https://www.dictionary.com/browse/scarcity

Something like "the first 20 people to click this link will win a prize"

questions.question_text:
Recently several employees were victims of a phishing email that appeared to originate from the company president. The email claimed the employees would be disciplined if they did not click on a malicious link in the message.
Which of the following principles of social engineering made this attack successful?

discussion.content:
Message Digest 5 (MD5) is a common hashing algorithm that produces a 128-bithash. Hashes are commonly shown in hexadecimal format instead of a stream of 1s and 0s. For example, an MD5 hash is displayed as 32 hexadecimal characters instead of 128 bits
SHA-1 is an updated version that creates 160-bit hashes. This is similar to the MD5 hash except that it creates 160-bit hashes instead of 128-bit hashes
DES is an encryption cipher. MD5 is old and subject to vulnerabilities and collision. So MD5.
Thought B, from the book "The RACE Integrity Primitives Evaluation Message Digest (RIPEMD) algorithm was based on MD4." So, If RIPEMD-160 then should be C, unless I'm missing something....

comments.content:
SHA and RIPEMD are both 160 
Weakest is MD5
this explanation makes more sense to understand the answer choice. easy to see how MD5 is the least secure and it is also known to be broken and generating collision.

MD5 is a hashing algorithm.
DES is an encryption.
So, should be C - MD5.

discussion.content: MD5 is 128bit, but DES is only 56 bits. I go with D

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the LEAST secure hashing algorithm?

An employee uses RDP to connect back to the office network.
If RDP is misconfigured, which of the following security exposures would this lead to?

choices.D: A man in the middle attack could occur, resulting the employee's username and password being captured.
choices.C: A social engineering attack could occur, resulting in the employee's password being extracted.
choices.B: Result in an attacker being able to phish the employee's username and password.
choices.A: A virus on the administrator's desktop would be able to sniff the administrator's username and password.
